Here's Jordan Rochester at Nomura

BE11:13am

Is election positive for GBP? I argue no. But some argue it could be as election = Boris majority = deal = stable government. But this would ignore that the past nine years of UK elections have actually been very unpredictable! As I argued in the piece below, the campaign will see polling swings, and investor inflows may slow whilst they wait for the result. It’s why we are long EUR/GBP.

tangledodyssey Argentina has decided to trust the Peronistas once more.
11:13 am
BE11:13am

That's from last week, this is the AM update.

BE11:13am

Still long EUR/GBP, looking for 0.8750 to 0.8850 as the hope of a Brexit deal passing parliament should fade and an election leads to 6 weeks of uncertainty. I’m more confident in the view given talk of passing the WAB is at a low and investors won’t be as convinced by the Conservatives lead learning from past lessons of 2017

nightingale20201 cant believe HSBC result (2 quarters earlier) were pretty positive and now (dead in ditch)
Forester I normally look at the betting exchanges for a good handle on what is going to happen (Brexit in 2020 is 1.60) however there is so little money on the table clearly not even punters have the foggiest about how this will play out!
BE11:14am

2. For USD based investors we also expect GBP/USD to head lower, we have a host of potential reasons for USD strength this week. Euro inflation (market expects to fall), the Fed (we expect a cut, but further easing to have a high hurdle) and US GDP on Wednesday. But also the re-starting of ECB QE, US NFP and US ISM (we expect a 2.7pp bounce!) on Friday. In short, the risk reward remains that EUR/USD has ended its mini uptrend and we could have a few USD positive surprises this week, the path is still a lower EUR/USD in our view

JuB cant believe they are closing down Markets Live ... How can we REMAIN in Markets Live ... can we put this to a vote ?Maybe we should have a 'Markets Live must Remain' party
tangledodyssey Clever of the LibDems, they may be aiming to be the official opposition by seeing Labour wiped out all over.
tangledodyssey Clever.........

BE11:15am

Tonight's vote should fail as the FTPA 2/3rds majority leads to Boris getting to choose the date after the vote has taken place and MPs have little trust in the leadership.

nightingale20201 @tangle (re Arg)...yes....that will come with austerity..etc

Taken For A Ride That Burford / Petersen case was put back to ealry Nov hearing presumably in the hope Macri would get reelected and be politically able to settle the case. Not so likely that the Peronistas will see things that way.
11:16 am
BE11:16am

Lessons from History: GBP rallied on the day in April 2017 by 1.3% when an election was called (as it would offer a Brexit majority for a deal....). It was the peak of optimism and GBP sold off 6% vs EUR in the months that followed. "Fool me once, fool me twice." I doubt the market will buy GBP to that amount as positioning is not as short as before.

rw42 I'm still morbidly interested to see if there are really as many people that still want brexit as the press seem to assume. I was fairly ambivalent at last referendum but i'd never vote conservative again after they mess they've made!
Electric Dragon Predictions are hard, especially about the future.
nightingale20201 someone could help me out here, please.... ...if there were a GE , is there a huge difference between Dec 9 and Dec 12????
BE11:17am

Once election starts, expect lots of predictions about a Tory lead and strong campaign, the Betting market has Tories majority at 49% probability. Political pundits ave done an awful job in the past as the truth as the 6 week campaign is very unpredictable. I expect The Brexit party to campaign hard and eat away at the Tory lead. Different to 2017, the Lib Dems could do well and this makes predicting the outcome of marginals even more difficult.

tangledodyssey Yes, the Peronistas are unpredictable. In charge of a country on its uppers once more. Burford may win but to collect might be rather more difficult.
Grouchmonkey @tangled my assumption was that they were only pretending support for a GE because they knew there would not be one (no support from Labour, nor remain-tory rebels (current situation better for them than an effective Tory majority) note DUP (makes current WDA more likely)
BE11:17am

Keep forgetting the Brexit Party's an actual thing rather than, I dunno, a phone-in segment on local radio.

Trading challenges "particularly UK unflavoured gin market where we had fewer promos and retail distribution declined by c100 outlets". Co sees "further softening of the unflavoured gin category into the foreseeable future". Per latest market data, the gin market saw a slowdown during the summer of traditional, unflavoured gin, overall category vol sales down in the 12 weeks to mid-Aug 2019.

Irish HF guy In Peaky Blinders, the men typically drank Whiskey (mostly Irish) and the Ladies typically drank Gin! Pink Gin is all the rage now. I have some Rubharb Irish Gin at the moment
BE11:23am

What does this mean for FEVR? Whilst we do not see a perfect read between Distil and the prospects for wider gin, (1) unflavoured is in decline (2) the market is crowded (3) some signs of increased promotional pressure. UK Nielsen remains tough, which will likely continue to weigh on FEVR shares given the hiatus between UK growth before US accelerates.

marktime So (even) good gin needs a mixer, but (especially) good whisky should not

Indian arbitration didn't go to plan.

Grouchmonkey @Irish - Gordon's. His recipe for a martini cocktail is in Casino Royale
11:30 am
BE11:30am

In the sense that it's been pushed back yet again, so falls out of 2019 as a catalyst.

BE11:30am

Barclays:

BE11:30am

The tribunal has informed Cairn that it expects to be in a position to issue an award during the summer of 2020, 6-9 months later than the company’s previous hopes/expectations. Cairn remains very confident in its claim for restitution of losses exceeding $1.4bn.

This update delays a potential late 2019 catalyst, where the outcome could add or remove 88p/shr from our 253p/shr Tangible NAV. We believe the market continues to assign a probability of a tribunal ruling in Cairn’s favour at well below 50%.

11:30 am
BE11:31am

As for the duster ....

BE11:31am

The company’s first exploration well on Block 9 (CNE 50% and operator) failed to find hydrocarbons. The rig is to move to the second drilling location and begin the Bitol-1 well during November. Cairn is also participating in 2 Eni-operated wells elsewhere in Mexico, the first of which is underway – Saasken-1 on Block 10 (CNE 15%).

While Mexico is far from a frontier region, it is relatively new for international explorers and our Tangible NAV and Price Target does not include any value for Cairn’s 2019 campaign. A commercial discovery at the Bitol-1 prospect could add 10-15p/shr to our Cairn valuation.

Irish HF guy @Grouchmonkey, okay, hence the cementing of Gordon's in the Gin chronicles. Diageo brand I might add.
BE11:31am

And Morgan Stanley.

11:32 am
BE11:32am

Further delays to the timeline on Indian tax arbitration award - now expected in summer 2020: Cairn noted that the Arbitral Tribunal issued, for the first time this year, new guidance that it will likely be in 'a position to issue the award in the summer of 2020'. This is further away from the company's expectations of a 'late-2019' decision. Given that the latest timeline was issued by the tribunal, we believe there is more weight associated with this, although the tax dispute with India has already been plagued by significant delays.

BE11:33am

We continue to believe that the Indian tax arbitration remains a wild-card for Cairn's NAV, with potential material impact that is very difficult to predict. We see the value ranging from 0p to 200p/share and our base case NAV incorporates a risked 20p value. With decision date now shifted by 9-12 months, the entire issue will now likely remain unresolved till at-least mid-2020.

BE11:33am

In addition, Cairn noted a disappointing debut in Mexico exploration: Cairn's first exploration well in Mexico - Alom 1 (Block 9, Cairn 50% and operator) - turned out to be dry. We note this is the first of the four well 2019 Mexico exploration campaign and representing ~140 mn bbls of gross resources of gross mean prospective resource target of ~550 mn bbls. The rig is now expected to move to drill the company second operated well in Block 9 - Bitol-1 (target gross resources ~180 mn bbls), where a result is likely to come by year end. The company noted that Bitol-1 will be targeting a different play compared to Alom-1 and, as a result, there is limited read across from Alom-1 to Bitol-1. In addition, the company also highlighted ongoing drilling at the non-operated Saasken well in Block 10 (Cairn stake 15%, gross resources 80 mn bbls). We believe there is little value related to Mexico within the current share price. Still, a disappointing result on the first well in a potential play opener for the company will likely be received negatively. Senegal FID and/or any data points highlighting progress to FID - 'key' catalysts till end-2019: During the 1H19 conference call, management stressed that the FID for the Senegal project will be taken by year-end. This remains our base case assumption as well. Delivery of the FID and/or any data points highlighting progress towards FID will act as a positive catalysts for the shares, in our opinion. On this, company highlighted that it expects to get the government approval on the exploitation plan within the next couple of weeks.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

You get the idea.

A. M. (morning all)

Straight miss, and it seems to be battening down the hatches that's done it.

BE11:42am

Caz:

BE11:43am

HSBC’s 3Q results are 5%/6% below our and company consensus PBT
expectations, driven mainly by higher than expected Impairments (CoR rose to 34bps in Q3 from 22bps in Q2) with an underlying NIM decline of 1bp. The outlook is notably cautious with management indicating that the outlook for revenue growth is weaker now than was anticipated at H1’19 and hence the group no longer expects to achieve its 2020 ROTE target of greater than 11% (cons already at 9.8%). Management also indicate that parts of the group - Continental Europe, UK NRFB (esp GBM) – have too much capital allocated or do not generate sufficient returns (US GBM & Retail) and actions will be taken to rebalance capital, simplify the bank and reduce costs. These plans will be disclosed at or before FY19 results and the group also indicates that these actions or the environment could result in significant charges at 4Q19 or beyond with the overall focus on sustaining the dividend with CT1 greater than 14%.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

We remain Underweight HSBC and note that these results are a negative readacross to StanChart due to higher cost of risk, but we see valuations at StanChart more reflective of current challenges at 0.7x P/TNAV vs HSBC at 1.1x P/TNAV

Bluesky21 HSBC and StanChart are not the same business
Standard Chartered PLC (STAN:LSE): Last: 697.50, up 5.5 (+0.79%), High: 697.60, Low: 685.20, Volume: 1.25m
nightingale20201 Winters at STAN has been remodelling a HSBC v2 since taking over
Bluesky21 HSBC is much more retail-driven while StanChart is more corporate
BE11:44am

And Goldman off the conference call.

11:44 am
BE11:44am

Strategic review. The group acknowledged that returns in NRFB (continental EU
nand UK) and the US are not acceptable and that the group needs to reshape the GBM businesses in both in order to improve returns and ‘materially’ reduce capital allocation. The bank, however, sees a strategic need (being a global wholesale bank) of retaining a strong presence in Europe and the US. The bank expects to be able to free up capital and to redeploy it elsewhere (e.g. in GBM in Asia/MENA) and support dividend and buyback capacity. Measures undertaken could be different across the US and EU.

nightingale20201 tiled away from Indonesia and towards China with Korea as a base...and towards commercial/trade banking
BE11:45am

Markets business. Sees its FX franchise as a strong business line with a top 3
nposition globally delivering strong returns and providing high connectivity to the overall franchise, with other parts of FICC and equities having lower returns.

BE11:45am

Basel 3 completion. The bank believes timetable of completion to many looks
nambitious as questions remain on national implementations and on whether the UK going forward will need to comply with EU directives or not.

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Risk cost. The bank guided that it expects the cost of risk to remain at the lower
nend of a 30-40bp range based on the credit quality trends it is currently experiencing. The group added that it has c.US$400 mn overlay in the UK for Brexit-related charges, which could be revised depending on the outcome of Brexit.

BE11:45am

G-SIB buffer. The bank indicated that it expects an update on its G-SIB buffer
nover the next few weeks. The bank sees itself as being on the cusp of staying in the same bracket or moving one step higher. Even if the outcome of the review is a higher G-SIB add-on for the group (2.0% now), it doesn’t necessarily imply that the group will revise its current CET1 target, which stands at 14%.

BE11:46am

(Goldman's PDF writer always puts random invisible Ns at the start of paragraphs, hence "nambitious" and so on.)

BE11:54am

[A] takeover of Tiffany could make a lot of sense, for a number of reasons:

1. This is one of the most prominent jewelry brands in the world (only four sizeable brands exist in branded jewelry)

2. Tiffany has yet to express its full potential – for example in design jewelry and in watches;

3. It would offer a European conglomerate a more balanced exposure to the USA (better FX, lower risk of tariffs, etc.)

A. M. (@BornCynic: also, that -- http://martinislounge.blogspot.com/2010/04/perfect-martini-according-to-hawkeye.html)
Electric Dragon James Whistler: [makes amusing remark, alas lost to history]Oscar Wilde: I wish I'd said that.Whistler: You will, Oscar, you will.
BE11:54am

We know that prior to taking over Bulgari, LVMH had been interested in Tiffany in the past (and that a takeover was averted back then, largely using a spurious watch license with Swatch Group as a poison pill). While we have no information whatsoever on a possible deal, we believe that this could be again on the menu in theory, as the integration of Bulgari has been very successfully accomplished.

11:55 am
BE11:55am

Combining Bulgari and Tiffany could make LVMH an even stronger contender in jewelry, even if Richemont holds the top brand with Cartier, and probably the best high-end brand with Van Cleef & Arpels.

BornCynic @A.M. - good one.
JuB cant believe they are closing Markets Live ... unbelievable ... part of whats great about the FT, innovation like ML
A. M. @BornCynic: they had good writers.
BE11:57am

And Morgan Stanley.

BE11:57am

Over the past decade, the share price of the acquiring companies in the Luxury Goods sector has generally fallen by around the amount of premium paid relative to the acquiring company's market capitalization (as the market generally doubts that synergies can be generated). Should the reported acquisition of Tiffany by LVMH materialize, this would suggest a c2% negative impact to LVMH's share price (Tiffany is covered by Kimberly Greenberger). As we explain below, a hypothetical transaction would carry a number of risks. One of the main risks relates to Tiffany's strong American DNA and LVMH's mixed track record with acquisitions in the United States. That being said, when it comes to acquisitions in jewellery, LVMH has a very strong track record (e.g. Bulgari). Tiffany's profitability relative to its size is significantly below industry average and we see a number of potential areas for material improvement. We remain Overweight LVMH shares. What's new? Saturday and Sunday, several publications (first Bloomberg, followed by the Financial Times and Reuters), citing several unidentified sources, reported that LVMH had approached Tiffany with a takeover proposal earlier this month. According to the Wall Street Journal, LVMH sent Tiffany officials a letter in the last couple of weeks outlining an all-cash takeover bid of roughly $120 a share. As per the different publications, Tiffany has hired advisers and is currently evaluating the bid and there is no guarantee an agreement will be reached. Both LVMH and Tiffany have declined to comment. This would be LVMH's largest acquisition, should a deal materialize. As of Friday's share price of $98.55, Tiffany's market capitalization and enterprise value stood at respectively $12.0bn (€10.8bn) and $12.1bn (€10.9bn). Assuming a share price of $118-138 (a ~20-40% premium to Friday's close, in line with previous large transaction in the space), Tiffany's market capitalization could reach ~€13-15.0bn. The acquisition of Bulgari in March 2011 (for a total consideration of €4.3bn) is LVMH largest acquisition to date. On a relative basis, however, the transactions would be broadly similar: EV/mkt capitalization of 8.5% for Bulgari in 2011 and about 7.5% for Tiffany today (assuming a premium of 20-40% and that a transaction goes ahead) - as of Friday, LVMH's market capitalization stood at €194bn. Looking at it another way, at $128 per share (the midpoint of a 20-40% premium), this would value Tiffany at about €14.0bn, less than one times LVMH's estimated EBITDA for 2019e (~€16.5bn)

BE12:00pm

Credit Suisse:

12:00 pm
BE12:00pm

With Strategic Value Back in the Spotlight…We Think TIF Is Worth Much More
than $120/Share: We’re raising our target price to $140 from $113. We think the
strategic value of this asset is significantly higher than LVMH’s $120/share offer, and
expect TIF to quickly dismiss LVMH’s initial proposal for 2 key reasons:
1) Recent Stock Peak: TIF traded at $140/share in 2018 (we think TIF’s Board will
be reticent to accept a bid below recent highs); and
2) 2x the EPS Power? A peer analysis suggests TIF’s underlying EPS power could
be as much as 2x higher than current Consensus 2019 ests.
We think the bid could reach $140 quickly (in-line with TIF’s recent high, or equity market
value of ~$17B). $140/share would imply ~17x Street 2019E EBITDA (above the luxury
peer avg of ~15x over the last 3 years) and ~17.6x ttm EBITDA (vs avg luxury M&A
multiple of ~19x).
■ Valuation: We’re raising our target price to $140 from $113 previously based on ~14x
our CY21 EBITDA (in line with the luxury peer group avg over the last 3 years and vs. our
prior 11x target EV/EBITDA). Our target price implies a P/E of ~24x our CY21 EPS (inline
with the luxury peer group avg over the last 3 years).

BE12:07pm

Here's William Blair.

BE12:07pm

LVMH and its competitor Kering are both underpenetrated in jewelry and watches, representing 9% and 7%
of sales, respectively, versus 22% of the total luxury market globally. It has also been one of the fastest growing categories in luxury,
next to shoes, both of which saw over 7% growth in 2018 (versus 5% for all luxury). Branded jewelry meanwhile only represents some
20% of the market, while growing numbers of self-purchasing (approaching a third of all diamond purchasing according to a 2017
study by DeBeers, up from 23% in 2005) suggests the growing importance of branding in the space.
We believe this all suggests that LVMH and even potentially Kering (though it remains a less viable bidder given its size) might be more
aggressive in pursuing Tiffany than they have in the past. Out-year expectations are relatively subdued for Tiffany, at a low-single-digit
comp and relatively limited margin expansion, with total operating margins resting close to 18%. There is likely significantly more
earnings power behind the brand, however, as the company continues to drive new marketing campaigns around fresher product and
shores up legacy supply chain inefficiencies, where there is likely also some significant synergies for a luxury conglomerate. As a result,
we could see the rationale for bidding to go higher. A $140 per share offer would value the company at 27 times near-year EPS, though
the theoretical multiple would step down to the lower-20 range if Tiffany margins were to approach luxury peers in the low-20%
range. Even without adjusting earnings, a $140 valuation represents EV/EBITDA of 16 times and close to 4 times sales, both of which
we believe are reasonable in the luxury sphere. LVMH bought Bulgari in 2011 for 24 times trailing EBITDA and 3.5 times sales. Given
the likely perceived importance of the jewelry space, limited options at scale (Chopard reportedly has close to $800 million in sales, but
the controlling family has rebuffed past offers), and the seeming incremental seriousness of this current offer, we expect Tiffany could
well be right to hold out for a higher offer or a competitive bidding process.
